block.p: Mideast Violence Subsides As Diplomats Confer Israelis and Palestinians haltingly backed away from confrontation as armed clashes subsided for the first time in 12 days, and a parade of diplomatic visitors urged both sides to rein in violence. There was one life-threatening casualty, a 12-year-old Palestinian boy in Gaza who was critically wounded.

Mideast Violence Subsides As Diplomats Confer Israelis and Palestinians haltingly backed away from confrontation as armed clashes subsided for the first time in 12 days, and a parade of diplomatic visitors urged both sides to rein in violence. There was one life-threatening casualty, a 12-year-old Palestinian boy in Gaza who was critically wounded.

Eight years of dealing with Yasir Arafat has left White House officials feeling exasperated, bewildered, even betrayed, as the Palestinian leader ignores their entreaties for the restoration of calm in the Mideast, officials said.
The Mideast violence has confused and angered American Jews, and left many more doubtful than ever that Mr. Arafat and his people truly want peace.

U.S. Sends Envoy to Beijing President Clinton dispatched his top trade negotiator to Beijing to warn the Chinese leadership that its efforts to back away from key trade concessions threaten the trading rights it won after a prolonged fight in Congress.

French Minister in Yugoslavia The world began to embrace the new Yugoslavia and its new president, Vojislav Kostunica, with the visit of the French foreign minister, Hubert Vedrine, representing the European Union.

North Korean at White House Mr. Clinton became the first American president to meet with a North Korean official, who carried with him a letter from the North's leader, Kim Jong Il, that White House officials said contained proposals for a further easing of tensions on the divided peninsula.

Zimbabwe Detains an Opponent The authorities questioned Zimbabwe's main opposition leader for two hours at police headquarters but delayed a decision about whether to arrest him. The police insisted that they still had enough evidence to arrest Morgan Tsvangirai for making a speech in which he told President Robert Mugabe, above, ''If you don't want to go peacefully, we will remove you violently.''

Second Debate Brings New Worries for Nominees Vice President Al Gore's aides have warned him that he had better watch his performance in the second debate tonight and not come on too strong, as many of his advisers said he did the first time. Mr. Gore's advisers said they were worried about a perception from the last debate that he embellished stories.

Neither Mr. Bush nor Mr. Gore has yet been able to pull ahead in the presidential contest, with each man's weaknesses becoming magnified in the minds of voters, according to five polls out this week. When the polls are averaged, Mr. Bush's support is 45 percent and Mr. Gore's 44 percent.
Bush campaign workers in Florida have mailed pamphlets to older Floridians that accuse Mr. Gore of planning to force elderly people into a ''government-run drug H.M.O.''

New Hampshire Acquits Justice The chief justice of New Hampshire's Supreme Court, David Brock, was acquitted overwhelmingly in his impeachment trial as the State Senate found him not guilty on four charges, including two of improperly allowing disqualified justices to comment on cases. It was the country's first impeachment trial of a state supreme court's chief justice.
Supreme Court Selects Cases The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the limits on the amount that parties can spend to help their congressional candidates are constitutionally valid.
The Supreme Court agreed to decide whether the government can keep a deportable alien behind bars indefinitely for lack of a country willing to accept him.
Physics and Chemistry Awards The Nobel Prize in Physics was awarded to three scientists who pioneered work on the microchip and semiconductors.
The Nobel Prize in Chemistry will be shared by three scientists who created a plastic that conducts electricity like a metal.

Lazio Looks Nationwide For Donations on the Web Representative Rick A. Lazio, the Republican Senate nominee, has mounted a nationwide television advertising campaign to raise money for his campaign against Hillary Rodham Clinton, running commercials on cable stations that ask people to call a toll-free number or go to his Web site to make donations.

Hostage Incident Ends During a prison interview, Kenneth Kimes, who was sentenced to 125 years after a series of crimes that culminated in the murder of an elderly Upper East Side socialite, took a Court TV reporter hostage for four hours, holding a pen to her neck. The reporter was eventually freed by prison officials.
Big Blue Chip Factory I.B.M. said it would spend $2.5 billion to build ''the world's most technologically advanced'' chip factory in East Fishkill, N.Y.
4 Indicted in Pensions Case After a year spent weighing evidence of corrupt investments in pension funds made by Connecticut's former state treasurer, a federal grand jury indicted four people.

Seattle Beats New York The Mariners defeated the Yankees, 2-0, last night in the opener of the American League Championship Series. Rickey Henderson, a former Yankee and Met, hit a run-scoring single in the fifth inning and Alex Rodriguez led off the sixth inning with a home run.

Technology Stocks Tumble Technology stock prices fell as fears spread that a slowing economy will drag down corporate earnings. Two prominent technology companies, Yahoo and Motorola, reported third-quarter earnings that respectively exceeded and met expectations, but investors sold those stocks after hours.
Lucent Technologies warned investors that earnings would fall short of expectations as competitors gnaw away at the company's business.

Houses Aims at Tire Companies The House of Representatives early this morning passed a bill that would raise civil and criminal penalties for failing to report defects in cars and tires. The vote came several hours after the chairman and chief executive of Bridgestone/Firestone Inc., Masatoshi Ono, resigned.

More Polar Route Flights A joint Canadian-Russian study has found that opening air traffic routes over the North Pole, currently used by two or three flights a day, to thousands of commercial flights a year is ''feasible and desirable.''

Vitamin Case Settlement New York State will receive $25 million out of the $255 million that six leading vitamin producers will pay to most states in the latest settlement of cases stemming from an international price-fixing scheme.
